render.tex: \title{Parametric Curves} What they are ; Finding a point, tangent or normal on the curve

reason.tex: %text Ordinarily, we expect curves to be of the form $y = f(x)$ But if both $x$ and $y$ are expressed in terms of a third variable/parameter, then we have what is called a \underline\text{parametric curve} And therefore, \underline\text{instead of one} $y = f(x)$ type equation, \underline\text{we will have two equations} -- both in terms of the parameter $(t)$ \[ \quad x = f(t) \text{ and } y = g(t) \] The curve is still plotted in $x-y$. It is only expressed in terms of $t$ \textbf{Coordinates of a point $A$ } A point $A$ on the curve will have the coordinates \[ \qquad A = (x,y) = \left(f(t), g(t) \right)\] \textbf{Slope of the tangent at $A$} The slope of the tangent will continue to be $\dfrac{dy}{dx }$. However, \[ \qquad\qquad \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \frac{dy / dt}{dx / dt}\] %
